comment_regular_data.body:
```
FAILED: touches/lintc-uncrustify/src-nvim-getchar-c /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/build/touches/lintc-uncrustify/src-nvim-getchar-c 
cd /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim && /usr/local/bin/cmake -E touch /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/build/touches/lintc-uncrustify/src-nvim-getchar-c && /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/build/usr/bin/uncrustify -c /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/uncrustify.cfg -q --check /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/getchar.c
FAIL: /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/getchar.c (File size changed from 99025 to 99027)
```

~~I don't know why it is failed.~~

I get it.  Fixed.
What is this providing that is not provided by `vim.on_key` ? Do we need both? Should we deprecate `vim.on_key` ?

OK.  `on_key` is good feature in neovim.  But it cannot change key behavior like `v:char` in `KeyInputPre`.

I heard about this problem from hrsh7th, the author of nvim-cmp.
So I have added the new feature.

Current `KeyInputPre` event problem:

The timing of updating `typedchar` is not intuitive.
It is updated when previous `KeyInputPre` until current `KeyInputPre`.
Can you fix it?

Requirements before merging this:

- deprecate `vim.on_key`
- `KeyInputPre` must provide all features of `vim.on_key` (including performance)

Else, let's mark these patches as N/A.

> OK. `on_key` is good feature in neovim. But it cannot change key behavior like `v:char` in `KeyInputPre`.

So raw input can be changed on the fly by plugins? That sounds like a potential source of very strange bugs.

When `KeyInputPre` and `vim.on_key()` both exist, there is also an ordering problem. Since `KeyInputPre` can change `v:char`, whether it is triggered before or after `vim.on_key()` affects what `vim.on_key()` receives.

> So raw input can be changed on the fly by plugins? That sounds like a potential source of very strange bugs.

The feature is needed to support in `nvim-cmp` `commitCharacters` feature.

> When KeyInputPre and vim.on_key() both exist, there is also an ordering problem. Since KeyInputPre can change v:char, whether it is triggered before or after vim.on_key() affects what vim.on_key() receives.

`KeyInputPre` is called after `on_key()` feature.
Also, `KeyInputPre` applies `textlock`, so it cannot replace `vim.on_key()`.

Hm....

I have set textlock in `KeyInputPre`.  Because it can change the text by `v:char`.

NOTE: `InsertChaPre` is also set textlock.

Not textlock is not danger?

labels.description: discussion has run its course, need decision how to proceed
labels.name: needs:decision
